fields.summary: Fails to load all AWS images

fields.description:
Unchecked the Owner filter, but the table doesn't load all aws images. The table lists only the images owned by 'me'.

The proxy has been running for an hour.

There's one browser session that actually loaded all images (and continue to show all), but other browser sessions for the same proxy doesn't show the aws images.

comments.body: This happens only with Oregon (us-west-1) region. The other regions work (though it takes quite a while).
Also, with proxy running on QA (remote), the enumeration often takes too long and the result is highly unpredictable (sometimes it doesn't show up).
Need to reproduce this and fix it if we can reproduce.
I've seen this same behavior. I'm not sure that its a particular AWS region. I think its simply intermittent.

Tested with AWS on both Oregon and N.California. On Chrome, I was able to load both regions images, over 10,000 images, and switch back and forth between the regions.

If it's a long term issue, I will have to keep the proxy running for over an hour, and come back to re-examine the condition.

As switching back and forth, I did see the condition where the browser's image landing page shows nothing, in turn resulting in the freeze in the screen.

The related issue is:

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-7908

The comment below is noted in the related bug:

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-7908

---

It turns out that when switching the AWS regions and receiving all AWS images causes significant memory leak on the browser -- Chrome in my case.

The initial memory usage of the UI, when logged, on was 7.2 MB. Upon the first viewing of the all AWS images on the region Oregon jumped the memory to be 65.8 MB. When switched over to N.California, it was at 107 MB, then going back to Oregon's image page caused the memory to go up to 155 MB. Repeating back and forth between Oregon and California, the memory size continuously goes up to 210 MB, 257 MB, etc.

Plus, another thing to notice is the number of the objects held by the browser, which was reached to 1.3 million objects with 1.0 million items in arrays. It is known that Firefox is not good at handling such a large size of arrays and strings.

In order to see the memory usage of the UI:

1. Open the UI on Chrome and log into AWS.
2. Open the Developer's tools on Chrome.
3. Select the profiles view on the Developer's tools
4. Perform the initial "Take Heap Snapshot" action to measure the initial memory usage.
5. Go to the image landing page and check out the all AWS images by clicking off the filter.
6. After the images are loaded, go to N.California region and check out the all AWS images in that region
7. Repeat the step 5 and 6 a few times.
8. As repeating the step 7 and 8, check the step 4 and compare the memory usage.
See the attachment for the outcome above.

Learned that this was not related to the switching the regions issue, rather without any region changes, I was also seeing the same issue where the console just idles when 'all AWS images' are selected. Ended up filing a bug as well:

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/EUCA-8186

When the AWS image filter is clicked off, the image landing page loads a small set of images that are owned by "me" first. In case of a bad network condition, there might exist a big delay between the initial load of the small image set -- in our AWS account, it was about 7 images -- and the following load of the all AWS images -- which is about 10K to 20K images.

This behavior gives a false impression to the user that the all AWS image loading has been complete when the first 7 images are loaded; not realizing that there are about 10K images are being loaded in the background (although in some cases, it was seen the following load of the all AWS images has been failed, thus left with only 7 images, however the frequency of this issue has been dropped significantly when tested on the latest maint/3.4/testing on 11/21/13).

So, for this release, I will look into options where this experience can be improved. In other words, when the AWS image loading is pending in the background, there needs to be a way for the UI to inform the user that the AWS image loading is whether in-progress or failed,

It was discovered that there exists a strange case where the "allimages" count was higher than the "images" count even if the all AWS images weren't loaded, which would prevent the all AWS images fetch call due to the condition below:

if (app.data.allimages.length <= app.data.images.length){
  .. fetch all AWS
}

This condition was adjusted, however, we will further look into the issue of why the "allimages" data contains random image information that didn't belong anywhere.

Pull Request at:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus-console/pull/244
